bug.short_desc: When a drive from a previous install is used on a new install, /home/user permissions could be wrong

long_desc.thetext:
If a drive from a previous install has user home directories and this drive is used on a fresh new install, it will be automatically mounted. When new users are created though with usernames similar to the one on the drive, there's a chance the UIDs won't match (since they might not be created in the same order). This will cause permission problems. One solution is to reset ownership on the /home/<new user> folder after creating the new user. Another idea is to keep two matching signatures, one on the system partition and the other on the /home partition. When there's a mismatch there will be UI to ask the admin what they want to do. An option is to move all existing /home/<username> folders to FamilyLibrary/olddrive or something. Please add ideas.
This is somehow related to bug 14524 so I'm adding a connection

Another approach (or possibly in conjunction with the signature approach) might be to write a generic "sanity" script (run @ bootup) that would check (and repair as appropriate) that: - all files have correct permissions and ownership - all UIDs used in /home have a matching entry in /etc/passwd (if missing, move to /home/oldrive or /home/orpan ?) - samba user conf matches /etc/passwd - other?

bug.short_desc: afp/netatalk does not work with the FamilyLibrary symlink

long_desc.thetext:
The netatalk implementation of afp does not deal well with symbolic links, which is how we give users access to /home/0common as ~/FamilyLibrary.
From the netatalk dox: "Don't use unix symlinks. Just don't. With a symlink a file/directory "exists" twice, something AFP doesn't allow. There's currently no way this can be resolved, as we either end up with two file/dirs having the same id, or a file having two parents. If you still insist on using them, be aware you're heavily violating the specs. You have been warned..."
There is a bug open w/ the netatalk dev on this issue: http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=525216
With DavidP's help, we have identified 2 workarounds:
- create a symlink with the same name (ls -s /home/0common /home/admin/0common). This is supported by the netatalk implementation (although as stated in the dox, discouraged.) This solution works, although shows an ugly directory name to the users, via all protocols (ftp, smb, our ui, etc...).
- instead of using a symlink, do a mount of /home/0common in each user's directory. eh: mount --rbind /home/0common /home/admin/FamilyLibrary. This solution is transparent to the user, however we would have to modify our user creation/deletion process to manage this mount in /etc/fstab. It would also require (significant?) testing for all protocols, including the flash UI.
Webdav also doesn't allow symlinks but we hacked it specifically and made an exception for /home/0common. It has worked without a problem. Just an observation

(In reply to comment #1) > Webdav also doesn't allow symlinks but we hacked it specifically and made an > exception for /home/0common. It has worked without a problem. Just an > observation
For whatever it's worth, if we use the rbind solution, I think that would mean we wouldn't need to hack webdav anymore, either. (This would need to be tested, of course.)
*** Bug 14877 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The rbind approach is definitely the best, most robust way to go. However, it will require a good deal of testing to make sure it does not break any of the access methods (flash client ui, ftp, aftp, smb, others(?) )

Our assumption across the OS is that FamilyLibrary is a symlink inside the user's home folder. I'm pretty sure we will encounter many problems if we change that. Let's hold off on considering this change for now. I'd like to take a look at the internals of atalk first and then we'll discuss. Re-adjusting estimate

So xfs has recovered and raid is recovering too.
Any idea what the following means? Filesystem "md0": Disabling barriers, not supported by the underlying device

From the XFS FAQ: http://xfs.org/index.php/XFS_FAQ --- Write barrier support.
Write barrier support is enabled by default in XFS since kernel version 2.6.17. It is disabled by mounting the filesystem with "nobarrier". Barrier support will flush the write back cache at the appropriate times (such as on XFS log writes). This is generally the recommended solution, however, you should check the system logs to ensure it was successful. Barriers will be disabled and reported in the log if any of the 3 scenarios occurs:
* "Disabling barriers, not supported with external log device" * "Disabling barriers, not supported by the underlying device" * "Disabling barriers, trial barrier write failed"
If the filesystem is mounted with an external log device then we currently don't support flushing to the data and log devices (this may change in the future). If the driver tells the block layer that the device does not support write cache flushing with the write cache enabled then it will report that the device doesn't support it. And finally we will actually test out a barrier write on the superblock and test its error state afterwards, reporting if it fails. ---

bug.short_desc: Improve Time Machine support

long_desc.thetext:
Right now, during setup, we ask user whether they want Time Machine to be configured. If they answer no we should give them the opportunity to do so at a later time.
The Configure Time Machine Scripts should be installed as part of the packages so user could run it any time they want. And we should inform users when they answer no that they can do it later.
*** Bug 14898 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

This bug now relates to making improvements to our support for Time Machine
We'll need these 4 items to be addressed: -Allow Time Machine to be configured later (4h) -Prompt users with backup volume size (with default volume size suggestion) 4h -Allow deletion of previous backup volume (4h) -Prompt users when previous Time Machine Setup is found (4h)

Update:
We've discussed this item and we've decided that we'll be using a 2 phase approach for the Time Machine (and Vista Backup) effort: Phase 1 (now): -Allow Time Machine to be configured later (4h) -Hard code the volume size to 200GB -Change documentation so users will be backing up to specific backup user account instead of their own account. This will allow us to introduce quotas in phase 2. -Prompt users when previous Time Machine Setup is found (4h)
Phase 2 (later, as an update): -Add a web service call to get quota from web server and create the backup volume sparse bundle with that given size. (4h)
adjusting estimates: 1 day for phase one.
